subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: The nature of things!
author: Frank Ratka
full_text:
--0-798058464-1250778303=:89783
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Your very right Frank, there are those science types out there that think "=
If its not measurable then its not tangible". There are many more out there=
 that are not! When I write of cognitive abilities I try to show the differ=
ence between perceiving physical things of this level of reality and the pe=
rception of non-physical things. Most psychologists today do not see the mi=
nd as a purely physical thing but more or less the brain as an instrument t=
o experience the world in which=A0we presently live. The mind and conscious=
ness is still very much a mystery. I have been an advocate of the "paranorm=
al" for a very long time and I am studying to finish up my master in psycho=
logy. When I say psychologists aren't the hardcore, "only believe in whats =
physical types" it comes from a position of experience. There are whole fie=
lds of psychology dedicated to how the mind interacts with the non-physical=
 (dreams, visions, psi-phenomena, etc). Perceived reality is reality
 Frank=
!

The rules of these scientists depend on the scientist and how the resear=
ch is structured. Scienctific method is a very flexible thing and most psyc=
hological research is based on statistical data. If people want to change h=
ow this research is approached then people from our perspective need to get=
 involved! Correct?

I'm with you on your perception statements. I have exp=
erienced altered states that involved astral sight, OBE's and other things.=
 I have had experiences where I would be writing with a pencil on a piece o=
f paper only to "snap out of it" and realize it is really a mouse in my han=
d and I never noticed the transition to the pencil in the first place. 

Do=
n't feel like we are all still considered crack-pots, flakes or some other =
bullshit label because we experience the things we do. We are no longer vie=
wed like that, well at least not in the psychological field. Two of my frie=
nds and people who helped me a lot with my early research are well-known an=
d respected physicists and their histories include one heading up and runni=
ng the US governments remote viewing program that ended in the 90's and the=
 other was a senior researcher with PEAR at Princeton. They now research fa=
ster than light travel, warp drives, and wormholes for the US governement a=
nd NASA though they have their own institute. Point is we have friends in a=
ll fields of science!

Regards,

Frank R.




_____________________________=
___
From: purplespacefriend <purplealiengirl@...>
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogr=
oups.com
Sent: Thursday, August 20, 2009 8:55:55 AM
Subject: [EVP-ITC] Re: =
The nature of things!

=A0 
I think the mind is not physical, and it's only=
 these paranoid scientist types that try to bully everyone into that extrem=
emly narrow thinking that everything experienced is physical phenomenon onl=
y, and must be made to fit into that context. 

Just because speech is all =
perception does not make invalid--that even normal speech is highly subject=
ive. If you used the rules of these scienctists, you couldn't even trust wh=
at the guy sitting next to you was saying. You couldn't trust what you were=
 hearing!

Perception is everything. How is it that just before some mass d=
eath thing, like a plane crash or some disaster I see the shadows shift, it=
 should not be possible, but never the less, I've seen it happen over and o=
ver. These scientific types brain wash everyone into not looking at clouds =
as you might imagine you see something--well a day or two before tornados i=
n other states I see circles in the clouds here-hundreds of miles away. Peo=
ple see me looking up and look at me like I'm insane because of these bully=
 skeptics. You're not allowed to perceive anything unless they tell you it'=
s ok. You can't look at clouds, and you can't listen to voices fragments, c=
uz they can't explain away the perceptions. These scientist types are too b=
rain dead to realize they too create thier reality-all those supposed new p=
articals did not exist before someone theorized about them, then they are c=
reated and "discovered" . 

Even it was all imagination, that does not make=
 it invalid or useless. It's still serves as personal insight. 

frank-S

-=
-- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com, Frank Ratka <warrior18eii@ ...> wrote:
>
> =
Assumptions and expectations! ? I hear a lot of both of these concepts in y=
our words and when mentioning your research. Cognitive functioning or proce=
ssing sensory information in order to come to a conclusion or judgement is =
how we function in this world. In order for your mind to understand this ph=
ysical world you live in it automatically makes certain assumptions about s=
ensory information it takes in. Your eyes expect to see objects oriented co=
rrectly, with the correct color, lighting, reflectivity and shading, and yo=
u expect there size and shape to be within scale compared to other objects.=
 My point is your senses have a range, which implies limitations. Since thi=
s is correct for your senses it is also correct for your ability to underst=
and perspectives with any wide ranging diversity. You are able to see and p=
rocess the information of our physical world just as any other human being =
does. That is great for a human but why would you think for a
 second,
> yo=
u could understand the perspective=A0of a mind and=A0 voice that speaks thr=
ough a radio from some unknown location.
> =A0
> The information you receiv=
e from the other side of your radios or even from thin air through EVP's co=
uld be completely correct and true no matter what the context because you d=
on't know what perspective it is coming from. You are making a lot of unfou=
nded assumptions about the (dare I say) beings or worlds they exist in and =
have a lot of expectations about the information you receive. You are looki=
ng for answers to the wrong questions! Quit assuming that these entities kn=
ow you or the people around you. Quit assuming they are here for your enter=
tainment as a personal fortune teller. Quit expecting them to know answers =
to question they may have themselves (just because they aren't physical doe=
sn't mean they know everything). Don't assume you will be speaking to a dea=
d relative or someone you once knew. Go to a fortune teller if you want inf=
ormation about the furture. If you are serious about researching these voic=
es and the equipment used to record them
> then ask the right questions. 
>=
 =A0
> If you have a box made by Frank then ask Frank how the different cir=
cuits work, what is the puropose of some of the options, why is the RVG bet=
ter or worse than a circuit without it? You have a unique situation here wh=
ere the inventor of an important piece of equipment is willing to share the=
 most minute details of how it works without a price tag attached. Some of =
the other box variations are sold by one person but created by someone else=
 and usually based on some loose design similar to Frank's. The other equip=
ment made by Bill Chapp and others will probably stay a mystery because the=
y are sold for profit. Most people who use the different "hacks" know how t=
o make them but don't know much about electronic theory or the behavior of =
radio waves to understand how they work.
> =A0
> Point is you have plenty o=
f questions to ask the human's who have built the equipment you are using b=
efore you can even begin to ask questions of the entities you are communica=
ting with.
> =A0
> Regards,
> =A0
> Frank R.
>
